entry.title: Plane crash in Nepal leaves at least 64 dead
entry.description: An aircraft carrying 72 people crashed in central Nepal's Pokhara on Sunday, the country's state media The Rising Nepal reported.

entry.title: How Ukraine became a laboratory for western weapons and battlefield innovation
Wagner leader posts video claiming victory in Soledar as Ukraine asserts that fighting continues
Europe answers Zelensky's longstanding call to supply modern battle tanks to Kyiv
entry.description: The Western alliance's response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine received a shot in the arm this week as multiple European nations for the first time answered President Volodymyr Zelensky's longstanding call to supply modern battle tanks to Kyiv.

entry.title: Putin gets angry and berates Russian official in public meeting
entry.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin sharply criticized one of his top officials at a public meeting for not delivering military aircraft quick enough. CNN's Clarissa Ward discusses the exchange and what Putin was trying to achieve.

entry.title: China reports nearly 60,000 Covid-linked deaths since dropping restrictions
Satellite images show reality of China's funeral homes
entry.description: CNN's Selina Wang reports on the reality within China as the country continues to contend with the onslaught of Covid cases after it abandons the stringent zero-Covid policy.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Asia's arms race risks spinning out of control
Two words no president ever wants to hear
'Command your troops, damn it!' How a series of security failures opened a path to insurrection in Brazil
Iran executes dual British-Iranian citizen Alireza Akbari
entry.description: • Analysis: Why an Arab nation has opted to teach the Holocaust in its schools

entry.title: 'Bodies in the way of the excavator': Thousands fight German village destruction
entry.description: It's a stark image in 2023: Police in riot gear flooding a village, pulling people out of houses and tearing down structures to make way for the arrival of excavating machines to access the rich seam of coal beneath the ground.

entry.title: Must-watch videos of the week
Miss USA R'Bonney Gabriel crowned Miss Universe
entry.description: R'Bonney Gabriel from the United States was crowned the 71st Miss Universe on Saturday night.

entry.title: See Miss Ukraine's war-themed costume
entry.description: During the national costume segment of the Miss Universe competition, some contestants chose to make political statements including Miss Ukraine, Viktoria Apanasenko, who made an impact with her reference to the ongoing war.

entry.title: Cracks running through this city are now so wide that hundreds of homes are no longer habitable
More than 80,000 people turn out for Tel Aviv protest against Netanyahu government
entry.description: Tens of thousands of people protested in Tel Aviv Saturday night against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government's proposed changes to the Israeli judicial system.

entry.title: 'It slowly spread like wildfire': Inside the symptoms of long Covid
More rain is on the way for weather-beaten California, where storms have flooded communities and left at least 19 dead
Luxury cruise ship comes face to face with migrant crisis
entry.description: Kester Howard was painting on a balcony of her luxury cruise ship when a startling announcement came over the loudspeakers.

entry.title: Americans are spending an extra $72 a month on food because of inflation
Cousin of Black Lives Matter founder dies from cardiac arrest after being tased by police
entry.description: A 31-year-old father and English teacher died from cardiac arrest last week after he was repeatedly tased by police, according to the Los Angeles Police Department, marking the third officer-involved death in the city this year.

entry.title: Bodycam captures police encounter with BLM co-founder's cousin before he died
entry.description: Bodycam footage from the Los Angeles Police Department shows an encounter with Keenan Anderson, the cousin of Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrisse Cullors, before his death.

entry.title: Australian Open: Novak Djokovic chases Rafael Nadal's record
From bottom of the league to title contenders. Five reasons behind Manchester United's remarkable resurgence
entry.description: For years, Manchester United ruled over English football, collecting 13 Premier League trophies between 1992 and 2013, as well as the world's best players and legions of fans.

entry.title: The 18-year-old phenomenon who could be the next great US women's soccer player
entry.description: Described by her new team Angel City as a "generational player," teenage sensation Alyssa Thompson made history on Thursday by becoming the first high school student to be drafted in National Women's Soccer League history.

entry.title: Lisa Marie Presley lived in a 'horrific reality' after her son's suicide
Travel news: Aviation meltdowns, China reopening and Mussolini's ghost
entry.description: In travel news this week, China reopened its borders, US aviation had another meltdown, and we take a look at Italy as a destination for history buffs.

entry.title: 2 Earth-size worlds revealed beyond our solar system
entry.description: There are more than 5,000 known worlds beyond our solar system.

entry.title: 'Nobody prepares you': Deeply personal photo series reveals heart of sandwich generation struggle
Attorney Woo and the rise of the K-drama heroine
entry.description: One of last year's most successful South Korean TV shows, "Extraordinary Attorney Woo," follows the story of a young autistic woman, Woo Young-woo, who navigates adulthood while winning cases at one of the nation's top law firms. Already renewed for a second season, it is now Netflix's sixth most-watched non-English television series and was recently nominated for a 2023 Critics' Choice Award.

entry.title: The chess variants changing the professional game for good
entry.description: From Netflix shows such as "The Queen's Gambit" to its rock and roll superstar Magnus Carlsen, the popularity of chess has never been stronger.

entry.title: Five famous artworks that were accidentally hung upside-down
entry.description: Art will always inspire and provoke, but it also continues to baffle and confound. To kick off the New Year, we look at some of the lighter examples of a world turned upside-down, with even some of the most experienced curators not quite getting the hang of it.

entry.title: The first Orient Express cruise ship will set sail in 2026
entry.description: Around 140 years after making its debut as one of the most luxurious trains in the world, the iconic Orient Express is branching out into the cruising world.

entry.title: The best islands in Europe for getting away from almost everyone
entry.description: From legendary nightlife hotspots to volcanic outposts far off the continent's mainland, Europe has islands in spades. But for every Mykonos, Ibiza or Santorini, there's someplace lesser known and equally lovely to escape to where you can ditch the crowds and get closer to nature.

entry.title: How the dream of moving to Italy turned sour for one family
entry.description: Making a move to Italy to start a new life in the sunshine, surrounded by beautiful scenery, incredible food and fascinating culture is a dream that many people have realized in recent years thanks to a sell-off of cheap homes.

entry.title: Video: Clumsy pandas capture hearts on livestream
entry.description: These cubs at Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding in China are dropping, flopping and rolling their way into our hearts.

entry.title: One thing you need in your kitchen to make cooking so much easier
entry.description: Before there were Crock-Pots and Instant Pots, slow cookers and air fryers, there was the Dutch oven. A multipurpose pot that has been a workhorse for cooks for centuries, it is one of the most useful, versatile pieces of kitchen equipment one can own.

entry.title: How to re-start your New Year's resolutions
entry.description: It's that time of year again.

entry.title: 82-year-old finally gets to retire after going viral on TikTok
entry.description: 82 year old Warren "Butch" Marion was able to retire after a TikTok user started a GoFundMe that raised over $100,000.

entry.title: Rihanna addresses new music hysteria in Super Bowl teaser
entry.description: It's been more than six years since Rihanna has released an album, and the roar of demand from fans for new music is deafening.

entry.title: How Ukraine became a laboratory for western weapons and battlefield innovation
entry.description: • Former Moscow-linked Church claims religious persecution as security raids heat up • Live updates: Death toll in Dnipro apartment attack rises to 20 • UK, France, Poland to send tanks to Ukraine

entry.title: Why Asia's arms race risks spinning out of control
5 additional pages of classified material found at Biden's Wilmington residence
entry.description: Fewer than 10 documents marked classified were found at President Joe Biden's residence in Wilmington, Delaware, according to multiple sources familiar with the investigation. None of the documents found at the home were top secret, the highest of the three basic levels of classification.

entry.title: A hairline crack became a 3-foot chasm. That's when he knew they had to leave
A new era for tennis begins at the Australian Open
entry.description: The first grand slam of the new tennis season gets underway on January 16 in Melbourne and the 2023 Australian Open is set to provide no end of intriguing storylines.

entry.title: 'It slowly spread like wildfire': Inside the dramatic symptoms of long Covid
entry.description: Jessica Rosario loved watching her 15-year-old, Eliana, play flute with the rest of the marching band during Open Door Christian School football games. But after the homecoming game in 2021, she got an alarming call from the Ohio school's band director.

entry.title: More rain is on the way for weather-beaten California, where storms have flooded communities and left at least 19 dead
entry.description: Storm-battered California -- still reeling from weeks of deadly flooding, mudslides and rescues -- is being hit with more rainfall over the weekend.

entry.title: Prince Harry's tell-all rips open old wounds in the British royal family
entry.description: Prince Harry's memoir has officially hit bookstores in the United Kingdom and elsewhere around the globe. Here in London, several retail chains opened their doors at midnight to allow eager readers to grab their copies before sunrise.

entry.title: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
entry.description: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.

entry.title: Hunting for Truffles Is a Perilous Pursuit, Especially for the Dogs Who Dig
entry.description: Truffles are big business, and some are trying to take out the competition by poisoning the dogs that accompany those known as “truffle hunters.”

entry.title: China Reports Nearly 60,000 Covid-Linked Deaths Since Lifting Restrictions
entry.description: The unexpected disclosure was made as the country faces mounting criticism for providing unreliable data on its latest coronavirus outbreak.

entry.title: German Village at Center of a Fight Over Coal and Climate Is Cleared Out
entry.description: For years, activists tried to save tiny Lützerath from being razed to make way for the expansion of an open-pit coal mine. This past week, the police moved them out.

entry.title: How Western Goods Reach Russia: A Long Line of Trucks Through Georgia
entry.description: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.

entry.title: Afghan Women Are Devastated by Suspension of Aid Under New Taliban Law
entry.description: Since the Taliban administration banned women from aid work, many groups have suspended their operations in the country and warned of permanently shutting down if the ban remains.

entry.title: She Witnessed Mao’s Worst Excesses. Now She Has a Warning for the World.
entry.description: At 93, the memoirist Yuan-tsung Chen hopes that her recollections of China’s tumultuous past will help the country confront its historical wrongs — and avoid repeating them.

entry.title: Investigation Blames Negligence, Poor Planning for Seoul Crowd Crush
entry.description: Investigators want 23 people indicted but cleared senior authorities of fault in the Halloween tragedy. Victims’ families disputed the inquiry’s findings.

entry.title: U.A.E. Names Oil Executive to Lead Climate Talks at COP28
entry.description: Sultan Al Jaber, who heads the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, was chosen by the United Arab Emirates to head the upcoming COP28 summit, drawing criticism from green groups.

entry.title: Biden’s Goals on Northern Ireland Present Difficult Timetable for Sunak
entry.description: The American president wants Britain’s squabble with Europe over Northern Ireland trade issues settled before the 25th anniversary of the peace accord that ended sectarian violence in the North.

entry.title: Israel Moves Right
entry.description: Israel’s new right-wing government is moving quickly to transform the country.

entry.title: Death Toll Rises After Russian Strike Destroys Apartment Block
entry.description: Rescue workers were still digging through the rubble of a residential building in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Sunday, a day after a Russian missile attack.

entry.title: For Families and Detainees in Russian-Occupied Areas, a Grim Wait
entry.description: After Russia’s retreat from Kherson city, Ukrainians in other occupied areas of the south had expectations of quickly regaining their freedom. But those hopes have been dashed.

entry.title: Plane Crash in Nepal Leaves at Least 68 Dead
entry.description: A twin-engine propeller plane crashed on approach to the city of Pokhara, with 72 people on board.

entry.title: ‘I’m Sorry, We’re From Moscow.’ In Bali, Warring Sides Learn to Cohabitate
entry.description: Thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have fled their homelands for Bali. But even in a tropical paradise, the war is ever-present.

entry.title: Britain Says It Will Give Ukraine Tanks, Breaching a Western Taboo
entry.description: Western countries have balked at giving Ukraine tanks and other powerful weapons. As increased spring fighting looms, that seems to be changing.

entry.title: Thousands in Israel Protest Netanyahu’s Plans to Limit Courts
entry.description: The right-wing government’s proposals for sweeping judicial reform are viewed by critics as anti-democratic and have galvanized the opposition.

entry.title: Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis to Face Off In Czech Republic Presidential Race
entry.description: Both candidates, Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis, are expected to foster closer ties to the West.

entry.title: Rescuers rush to save people buried in rubble of a building destroyed by a Russian missile.
entry.description: A 15-year-old girl was among the 14 people killed. The search for survivors continues.

entry.title: The Saturday morning attack on Kyiv appeared to best the air-raid warning system.
Cinema Studies
entry.description: Awards season has begun. It’s time to cram.

entry.title: The Dessert-First Author Whose Books Defined Canada’s Treats
entry.description: Jean Paré, the prolific, self-published cookbook writer, died last month in Alberta. Her unfussy recipes found an audience with millions of Canadians.

entry.title: Cooperation on Climate Is Emerging in the Middle East
entry.description: After the Abraham Accords, partnerships between companies in Israel and Arab countries have led to the kinds of initiatives that will be on the Davos agenda.

entry.title: Ecuador Moves to Expand Drilling in the Amazon
entry.description: A novel idea to leave the country’s vast oil reserves in the ground fizzled for lack of international support. Now, struggling under painful debt, the government wants to expand drilling in the rainforest.

entry.title: Davos Is a Winter Haven, Even With the Crowds
entry.description: Many tourist spots are shut down or blocked off during the World Economic Forum, yet there’s still plenty to do amid the clear air and mountain vistas.

entry.title: A United Europe Weathers Crises, but Deeper Challenges Remain
entry.description: Differences on NATO and E.U. enlargement, energy and climate, and relationships with the United States, China, Russia and Ukraine will prime Davos talks.

entry.title: World Economic Forum in Davos Confronts a New Order
entry.description: The Covid-19 pandemic, invasion of Ukraine, trend toward autocracy and economic inequalities challenge the World Economic Forum’s relevance.

entry.title: What Does the War in Ukraine Mean for the Climate?
entry.description: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.

entry.title: As Humanitarian Crises Escalate, So Do Demands to End Them
entry.description: David Miliband, head of the International Rescue Committee, says the global refugee crisis “is manageable, not insoluble.”

entry.title: Iran Executes Alireza Akbari, Ex-Official Accused of Spying
entry.description: Alireza Akbari, previously a senior military and defense official, had moved to Britain a decade ago. He had been detained since 2019.

entry.title: Bolsonaro Faces Investigation for Inspiring Brazil’s Capital Riot
entry.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said it would investigate Jair Bolsonaro, the country’s former president, for inspiring the mob that stormed the nation’s halls of power on Sunday.

entry.title: Biden Administration Faces Resistance to Plan to Sell F-16s to Turkey
entry.description: The State Department has contacted Congress about major arms deals for Turkey and Greece, but a prominent senator is strongly opposed to the Ankara sale.

entry.title: No Increased Stroke Risk Linked to Pfizer’s Covid Boosters, Federal Officials Say
entry.description: An uptick hinted at in surveillance data was a mirage, the officials said.

entry.title: How a Mob Tried to Oust Brazil’s Lula
entry.description: The storming of Brazil’s capital failed to overthrow the elected government. But an examination of the attack reveals how extremism is threatening Latin America’s largest democracy.

entry.title: Peter Grose, Veteran Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 88
entry.description: His career with The New York Times took him to Saigon and Moscow. He drew on that experience later to write several well-received books.

entry.title: Russia’s Claim to Seize Soledar in Ukraine Exposes Rifts Among Forces
entry.description: After Russia’s Defense Ministry said its troops had taken Soledar, a leader of the Wagner mercenary group accused the military of stealing credit. Ukraine said its forces were still fighting there.

entry.title: Greek Court Drops Espionage Charges Against Aid Workers
entry.description: The 24 defendants had been charged with misdemeanors over their work with migrants, but they still face more serious charges.

entry.title: Sweden Says It Has Uncovered a Rare Earth Bonanza
entry.description: A state-owned mining company announced it had found Europe’s largest deposit of the vital minerals used in electric vehicles and other green technology.

entry.title: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to 7 Charges of Sexual Misconduct in U.K.
entry.description: The Oscar-winning actor had already pleaded not guilty in July to five other counts of sexual misconduct. He is currently out on bail.

entry.title: Constantine II, the Last King of Greece, Dies at 82
entry.description: An Olympic medalist, he was popular when he took the throne in 1964. But his efforts to intervene in Greek politics led to a coup and his ouster.

entry.title: Biden and Kishida Vow to Bolster US-Japan Alliance as China’s Power Grows
entry.description: The two leaders discussed tensions with China, North Korea and Russia and plans for deterrence in Asia with U.S. troops and missiles.

entry.title: How the Biden Administration is Battling the Border Surge
entry.description: The Biden administration’s border policy relies on Mexico for crucial help.

entry.title: The Great New Zealand Egg Shortage
entry.description: Prices are up, and some parts of the country have seen bare shelves where eggs normally are. One reason is a change in how chickens are being raised.

entry.title: Western Tanks Appear Headed to Ukraine, Breaking Another Taboo
entry.description: The West has sent an array of weapons once seen as too provocative, and it looks like tanks will be next. With a new Russian offensive expected, officials see an urgent need to shift the balance.

entry.title: Your Friday Briefing: Investigating Chinese Police Outposts Abroad
entry.description: Also, Xi Jinping changes his tone on business and South Korea considers nuclear weapons.

entry.title: Girl Guides of Canada Drops Brownies Name
entry.description: The organization adopted a new name, Embers, for the branch after current and former members said that the old one was a barrier to belonging.

entry.title: Exxon Scientists Predicted Global Warming, Even as Company Cast Doubts, Study Finds
entry.description: Starting in the 1970s, scientists working for the oil giant made remarkably accurate projections of just how much burning fossil fuels would warm the planet.

entry.title: Sri Lanka’s Former President Ordered to Pay Compensation Over 2019 Bombings
entry.description: A Supreme Court ruling denounced former President Maithripala Sirisena and some of his top officials for what it called “reckless failure” to prevent the attacks, which killed more than 200 people.

entry.title: Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul Proposal Sets Off Fury in Israel
entry.description: A proposal to weaken the Supreme Court has set off an early backlash against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new hard-right government.

entry.title: Who Is Valery Gerasimov, the New Head of Russia’s War Effort in Ukraine?
entry.description: In a statement announcing the appointment, the Russian Defense Ministry hinted at a renewed campaign in Ukraine.

entry.title: Russia Released US Navy Veteran Quietly Detained for 9 Months
entry.description: The veteran, Taylor Dudley, had traveled to Poland to attend a music festival and “at some point crossed the Russian border,” a family spokesman said. It remained unclear on what charges he had been held.

entry.title: With FBI Search, US Escalates Global Fight Over Chinese Police Outposts
entry.description: Beijing says the outposts aren’t doing police work, but Chinese state media reports say they “collect intelligence” and solve crimes far outside their jurisdiction.

entry.title: In a First, South Korea Declares Nuclear Weapons a Policy Option
entry.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol said that if North Korea’s nuclear threat grows, his country may build a nuclear arsenal of its own or ask the United States to redeploy in the South.​

entry.title: Driver in Guangzhou, China, Runs Down Pedestrians, Killing at Least 5
entry.description: The police in Guangzhou detained a 22-year-old man, who appeared to throw money in the air after striking the people. Thirteen people were injured.

entry.title: Poland and Britain Consider Sending Leopard Tanks to Ukraine
entry.description: U.S. and European defense officials have long held concerns that giving Ukraine tanks could prompt Russia to escalate the war.

entry.title: Your Thursday Briefing
entry.description: Aides have found more files retained by President Biden dating from his vice presidency.

entry.title: Video Shows Brazil Rioters Breaching Inadequate Security
entry.description: The invasion of Brazil’s halls of power began with a severe shortfall of security forces.
